turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, I'm calling to follow up on my car insurance claim, claim number is 2023-10-26-4472. I submitted it last week after that minor fender bender.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Thank you for calling. Please allow me a moment to access your claim. Okay, I have claim number 2023-10-26-4472 in front of me. It appears it's currently under review by our claims adjuster. Is there something specific I can help you with today?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Well, yeah! I need to know when I can expect to get my car fixed! It's been a week, and I'm having to Uber everywhere. This is getting expensive and inconvenient. What's taking so long?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: I understand your frustration. The delay is likely due to the need to assess the damage estimates and verify the details of the incident. I will send a message to the adjuster handling your case requesting an update on the estimated completion timeline. You should hear back from them within 2 business days.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Two business days? Seriously? That's ridiculous! Can't you just tell me roughly how much they're likely to approve? The damage wasn't *that* bad, mostly cosmetic.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: I cannot provide an estimated approval amount at this time, as this is entirely at the discretion of the claims adjuster after review of all evidence. Multiple factors play a role, including repair shop rates and policy deductibles. However, I can confirm that your policy deductible for collision is $500.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, $500 deductible, I knew that. But what if the other driver was mostly at fault, even though we didn't get a police report? Would that affect my rates even though I'm filing the claim through my insurance?
